author: Svein
message:
Can the new crop mode be turned off? I really HATE getting things on top of the picture. I want it out and away. The crop as it is now is almost ok. There are a couple of things that could be added:

Set a fixed size and crop to it so it resizes and crops at the same time (like you can in Photoshop).

Apply the crop by pressing Enter so you do not have to click on the Crop button.

In addition, there are a couple of things I am missing from Gwen:

I want to be able to set both horizontal and vertical number of pixels when I resize. It is not always the horizontal number of pixels that is the most important.

And a big one: I have not found out how I can save as PNG... Why? Right now, I have to open GIMP just because of this.

With these things in place, Gwenview covers 90% of the work I need to do on pictures for web.

If we can get some advanced settings for tweaking quality, compression etc. for the different formats similar to the "Save for web" settings in Photoshop, things would be perfect :-) I am not talking about the interface or the complete functionality, just the different settings.

replies.author: Aurélien
replies.message:
You can adjust horizontal and vertical number of pixels either by the handles or by turning on the "Advanced settings" and entering values in the width and height spin boxes.

You can save as PNG: just go to "File > Save As".

Other things you ask for are out of the scope of Gwenview in my opinion.

author: maniacmusician
message:
It's really great, using 2.3.0 at the moment. A couple of gripes / comments (doesn't everyone, though?):

- Can you include a configuration option for toggling video playback? Or at the very least, require the user to initiate playback when in "View" mode? It's really jarring to stumble upon a video while browsing a folder of images, and suddenly have blaring, too-loud audio hit you in the face because the volume for the video was set too high.

- The Page Up and Page Down buttons seem to move the user to the next or previous image, which I believe is an incorrect behavior for two reasons: (1) This action is already assigned different default shortcuts (Space, Backspace). (2) I think PgUp & PgDn have traditionally been meant for navigation within the loaded document, or in this case, image. This is most apparent when dealing with vertically large images, such as standard page scans (which also encompasses comic books, mentioned by another commenter)

I thought the second bullet might be an issue with my shortcuts configuration, but it was the same on a fresh account. It's also weird that it does this despite having different values set in the Configure Shortcuts dialog. When I try to set Next to PgDown in order to use space / shift + space for vertical navigation, it denies me and says that PgDown is ambiguous, though it doesn't seem to be.

Anyways, those have really been the only things for me that were worth a complaint, which is saying a lot. Brilliant job on this application.

author: John S
message:
When I finally get around to trying Gwenview, one thing that irritates me is that I can't choose the zooming algorithm. From what I understand, there used to be an option in the past or something.
Every other image viewer has it, or uses a sensible algorithm by default. So perhaps this is not Gwenview's fault and there is a hidden setting somewhere? Currently using v 2.2.2 and wondering if there's an option in the next version.

I myself don't need any fancy image manipulating at all in my viewer, or video support. But what I want is a consistent viewer for all my images with some tag support (.svg and .gif, wow), and Gwenview is just that kind of program. Better startup time is always good, even though I'm not hoping it will be as quick as feh or anything.

replies.author: Aurélien
replies.message:
Please define "sensible algorithm".

Gwenview algorithm uses smooth zoom if zoom <= 2 and fast zoom otherwise, on the basis that if the user zoom the image more than twice, he is more likely to be interested in crisp pixel representation, for example to fine-tune a crop. It&#039s a sensible algorithm to me :)

replies.author: John S
replies.message:
Saying 'zooming algorithm' was definitely a bit ambiguous of me there. Perhaps resampling algorithm? Luckily it looks like you understood my rambling there.
But what you said is interesting, it seems it is indeed a feature, like in this pic, at 25% Gwenview would start to behave like gThumb, and then at 200% the pixels would be crisp.
http://i29.tinypic.com/37l1...

I might understand the reasoning behind that choice. Then again I might not, who knows. Just that I usually have multiple, small windows open, and such 'distorted' images certainly aren't the best visual clues, especially if there's text/graph involved (sometimes white text would turn bluish). I'm definitely not complaining about the pixels being crisp at 200% however, that's a much needed one.
Sorry if I didn't get why you did it. An option would be very nice, or you could make it smooth by default methinks...

replies.author: Aurélien
replies.message: I understand better now. So you would like a nicer scaled output? For now Gwenview uses Qt scaling algorithms. I might try to implement nicer algorithm later, but it's quite low in my TODO list.

author: Staffan
message:
It would be nice to be able to disable video viewing. Or at least, make them not start automatically.

I often open up my download folder and start gwenview to look through all downloaded images. Often there happens to be a video downloaded as well, and I usually am not interested in looking at it while browsing through the images. Right now, I had about ten videos and five photos and had to click on each photo one after the other (in dolphin) to avoid starting a lot of videos while looking at photos.

replies.author: Aurélien
replies.message:
Unfortunately, I was short of time to implement this. A workaround can be to filter out the videos:
- In "Browse" mode, Click on "Add Filter" in the status bar
- Select "Filter by Name"
- Select "Name does not contain"
- Enter something like ".avi" (or whatever your videos are) in the text entry
